Cu-added γ-Al2O3 (CuAl) catalysts having varying Cu loadings (3, 5, 8, and 10 mol%) were prepared at 900 °C. The effects of the copper oxidation states and the stability of these states under oxidizing and reducing atmospheres were examined. The use of these materials as three-way catalysts (TWCs) was also assessed. Analyses by X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy indicated that copper oxide species were well dispersed and formed a solid solution in a surface layer of the γ-Al2O3. The TWC activity was found to increase with the addition of copper, and the 8 mol% CuAl catalyst showed very high performance despite being heat-treated at high temperatures. In the case of the 10 mol% CuAl catalyst, the excess Cu loading resulted in the precipitations of copper species on the γ-Al2O3 surface, which decreased catalytic activity. The oxidation states also differed between these catalysts. X-ray absorption fine structure and temperature-programmed reduction data demonstrated variations in copper oxidation states among the catalysts before and after oxidation and reduction treatments. The 8 mol% CuAl catalyst had a high Cu+/Cu2+ ratio and contained stable Cu+ species during both oxidation and reduction trials. The stability of the copper oxidation states is evidently a factor affecting catalytic activity. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Al2O3 Cu Three-way catalyst NO reduction Chemical state Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The exhaust gases emitted by combustion engines contain hydrocarbons (HCs), carbon monoxide (CO), and nitrogen oxides (NOx), which can produce photochemical smog and acid rain. As a result of the environmental issues associated with automobile exhaust, regulations concerning the treatment of these emissions are becoming increasingly strict worldwide. Hence, the post-treatment of these pollutants is now an important issue. So-called three-way catalyst (TWC) systems have long been recognized as the most efficient approach to the simultaneous conversion of CO, HCs, and NOx in exhaust to CO2, N2, and H2O. Conventional TWCs consist of finely dispersed active species, such as precious metals, supported on ceramics [1–9]. Al2O3, in particular, has numerous applications as a support for environmental catalysts [2–4,10–14], and γ-Al2O3 and modified aluminas are used in exhaust treatment systems based on the high surface area and thermal stability of these materials. TWCs are known to be deactivated as a consequence of thermal degradation involving the sintering of active species and support materials during exposure to high-temperature exhaust gases. So these catalysts must be stabilized without diminishing their activity. As noted, precious metals are frequently used in such catalyst systems as highly active species and, in particular, are widely used for the purpose of exhaust gas purification. Unfortunately, these metals have become increasingly rare based on the remarkable expansion of demand, so there is currently much interest in finding less expensive alternatives [13–20]. Consequently, much research has been performed that has focused on the catalytic properties of less rare transition metals [13,14,20]. Such studies have shown that copper is able to promote both oxidation and reduction reactions [10,20–33], and copper species highly dispersed on Al2O3 have greatly enhanced the rates of NO-CO and NO-HC reactions [28–33]. This high activity level is attributed to the specific copper phases formed on Al2O3 supports. Below a certain loading value, copper species tend to migrate into the surface of an Al2O3 support at high temperatures, resulting in a thin, defective spinel layer with different physical and chemical characteristics from bulk CuO [33]. Therefore, controlling the state of copper species in the surface layer on γ-Al2O3 might affect the catalytic activity of the material. Even so, the effects of the composition in the low-content region of copper species have not been clarified. This work evaluated the catalytic performance of catalysts comprising CuO on γ-Al2O3 supports (CuAl) having various compositions, prepared by heating in air at 900 °C. The effects of the chemical states of the catalysts and of stability in response to oxidizing and reducing conditions on TWC activity were assessed. The present study aimed to evaluate TWCs incorporating copper and elucidate the states of copper species dissolved in the γ-Al2O3 supports, which may affect catalytic activity. Catalysts were prepared in a manner that was expected to provide a stable composite material with well-dispersed active species throughout a surface layer on the γ-Al2O3 in addition to high thermal stability. The relationships between the activities of these materials and morphological and/or chemical characteristics were investigated. 2 Materials and methods Cu was added to Al2O3 acting as a support to give Cu loadings of 3, 5, 8 and 10 mol% relative to the amount of Al2O3 by immersion of Al2O3 powder (Sumitomo Chemical, Japan) in an aqueous solution of Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O (Wako, Japan). The resulting composite oxides were dried overnight at 110 °C and then heated at 900 °C for 3 h in air. The crystal structures of the catalysts were subsequently evaluated by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD; Rigaku MiniFlexII) with a Cu Kα X-ray source operating at 15 kV and 30 mA. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM; JEM-2100plus, JEOL) was used to observe the morphologies of the catalysts and the distribution of copper species on the Al2O3. Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) in conjunction with energy dispersive spectroscopy (Gatan) was also employed to determine elemental distributions. Brunauer, Emmett and Teller surface areas were calculated from the nitrogen adsorption isotherms acquired from these materials at − 200 °C using a Micromeritics Tristar apparatus. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) data were obtained to determine the reduction behavior over the CuAl catalysts at various temperatures. These trials were performed using an apparatus of our own design together with a quartz microreactor and a thermal conductivity detector to monitor gas composition changes. In each trial, a flow of 5% H2 in Ar was passed over a 0.1 g sample of powdered catalyst while heating the material from 40° to 600°C. The TPR profiles were generated based on the detector signals reflecting H2 consumption (in arbitrary units) versus temperature. Following each TPR experiment, the catalyst was again heated at 600 °C for 20 min under a flow of Ar, after which oxidizing conditions were applied. Finally, the sample was cooled, and a second TPR trial of the same sample was performed without changing the conditions. The activities of the TWC materials were evaluated in a fixed-bed flow reactor system incorporating a quartz microreactor and using a stoichiometric gas mixture (0.3% CO + 0.04% C3H6 + 0.1% NO + 0.33% O2 + 0.1% H2 + 2% H2O by volume, balance N2) flowing at 500 ml min−1 (equivalent to a space velocity of 360,000 l kg−1 h−1). In each trial, a 100 mg quantity of catalyst was placed in the reactor, and the activity of this material was evaluated by raising the temperature from ambient to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1. After cooling, a second TWC evaluation was subsequently performed by raising the temperature from ambient to 600 °C at a rate of 4 °C min−1 without changing the sample and using the same conditions. The concentration of C3H6 exiting the reactor was determined using a Shimadzu VMS-1000 F analyzer, while the concentrations of CO, CO2, NO, and O2 were determined with a Horiba PG-240 analyzer. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) data were acquired near the Cu K-edge (8980 eV) at room temperature on the BL11S2 beamline at the Aichi Synchrotron Radiation Center. X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) oscillations were analyzed to determine local structure parameters around the X-ray absorbing atoms using the Athena code. 3 Results 3.1 Crystal phases and morphologies Fig. 1 shows the XRD diffraction pattern of each CuAl catalyst. Several peaks in these patterns were attributed to γ-Al2O3 having a defective spinel structure (JCPDS 50–0741), and these peaks were shifted to lower angles as the copper content was increased. These results suggest that the surface spacing increased as Cu2+ ions (having a larger ionic radius) were substituted for Al3+, indicating the partial formation of a solid solution based on the dissolution of copper species at the surface of the γ-Al2O3 [32]. The crystallite sizes calculated from the (440) peak intensities using the Scherrer equation were 6.5, 6.7, 7.0, and 7.3 nm for the 3, 5, 8, and 10 mol% CuAl catalysts, respectively. Thus, as the copper concentration was increased from 3 to 10 mol%, the crystallite size slightly increased. The specific surface areas (SSAs) were determined to be 101 m2/g for both the 3 and 5 mol% CuAl catalysts and 91.6 and 81.5 m2/g for the 8 and 10 mol% CuAl catalysts, respectively. Assuming spherical particles, we can write A = 6/ρD, where A is the SSA in cm2/g, ρ is the density of the material in g/cm3, and D is the mean diameter of the particles. Using this equation, A values were calculated based on the relationship between the 3 mol% CuAl catalyst and the others, and values of 98.0, 93.8, and 90.0 m2/g were determined for the 5, 8, and 10 mol% CuAl catalysts. These calculated values were higher than the SSA values for these same catalysts. These results suggested that the incorporation of Cu2+ ions induced the growth of the crystalline γ- Al2O3 phase in these catalysts, resulting in a slight decrease in the SSA. Fig. 2 presents TEM images and elemental maps obtained from STEM images of the 5, 8, and 10 mol% CuAl catalysts. The TEM images demonstrate that γ-Al2O3 particles having sizes on the order of several nm were present, in agreement with the crystallite sizes calculated from the XRD patterns. In addition, the elemental maps confirm that copper species were dispersed over the surface of the 5 mol% catalyst (Fig. 2(A)). Neither the high magnification TEM nor the element map show any evidence of aggregation of these copper species in the images of 5 and 8 mol% CuAl catalysts (Fig. 2(B) and (C)). In contrast, the TEM image and elemental map of 10 mol% CuAl catalyst the precipitated species with < 2 nm were slightly observed and suggest the inhomogeneous solidus limitation in Cu-added Al2O3 (Fig. 2(D)). Since STEM images reflect information from the electron beam transmitted through the catalysts, copper species might be uniformly distributed in the surface layer of the 5 and 8 mol.% CuAl catalysts. From these findings, it is evident that copper species were dissolved in γ-Al2O3. These catalysts evidently comprised Cu-modified alumina having a defective spinel lattice (Fig. S1), in agreement with a previous report by Ozawa et al. [32]. 3.2 Three-way catalytic activities Fig. 3 shows the TWC activities of the CuAl catalysts as assessed during the second run trials, while the light-off temperatures at 10% (T10) and 50% (T50) for each catalyst are summarized in Table 1. The T50 values for the CO oxidation reaction were determined to be 406, 388, and 365 °C for the 3, 5, and 8 mol% CuAl catalysts, respectively. These values, therefore, decreased with increases in the proportion of copper. In contrast, the T50 value for the 10 mol% CuAl was 396 °C and so was approximately equal to that for the 5 mol% CuAl. The order of reactivity in the high-temperature region was 8 mol% CuAl > 5 mol% CuAl > 10 mol% CuAl > 3 mol% CuAl. In the case of the C3H6 oxidation reaction, the T50 values were 441, 412, 378, and 462 °C for the 3, 5, 8, and 10 mol% CuAl catalysts, respectively, and so were very similar to those for the CO oxidation reaction. The same trend was also observed, in which the temperature decreased as more copper was added up to 8 mol% CuAl, with the highest temperature observed when using the 10 mol% CuAl. In the case of the NO reduction reaction, the conversion was only 70% when using the 3 mol% CuAl catalyst, even at 700 °C. However, 100% conversion was obtained at 700 °C with the 5 mol% catalyst and 660 °C with the 8 mol% catalyst. Interestingly, the 10 mol% CuAl provided lower NO reduction activity, as was also observed during the oxidation reaction trials, and the conversion exhibited by this catalyst remained at 90% even at 700 ℃. The order of reactivity of these catalysts based on T50 values was 8 mol% CuAl > 5 mol% CuAl > 10 mol% CuAl > 3 mol% CuAl. The 8 mol% CuAl catalyst provided the highest level of performance during oxidation and reduction reactions, exceeding those of the 10 mol% CuAl catalyst. For these catalysts, the specific surface area decreased with the proportion of copper. Since catalytic reaction occurs at the surface, this reduction in specific surface area might lower the activity. However, the activity increased up to 8 mol% CuAl catalyst in TWC evaluations. The greater performance of this catalyst can possibly be attributed to an increase in the number of active sites, suggesting that the Cu species were well dispersed in the surface layer on the Al2O3. In contrast, the decreased activity shown by the 10 mol% CuAl might have been a consequence of the precipitation of Cu particles, as observed by TEM images (Fig. 2(D)). The T10 values, which reflect the ease with which the reaction is initiated, indicated that the oxidation reactions of CO and C₃H₆ were initiated with increases in reaction temperature. These reactions were followed by the reduction of NO over each catalyst. It should also be noted that the conversion curves acquired during the NO reduction reactions each contained a small peak in the vicinity of 330 °C, possibly related to the adsorption of NO. Prior work with Al2O3-supported Cu catalysts has indeed confirmed that NO conversion often occurs later than reactions involving CO and C3H6 [34]. In the present study, 100% NO conversion was obtained using a model exhaust gas comprising CO, C3H6, NO, O2, H2, H2O, and CO2 at the highest space velocity (360,000 l kg−1 h−1) yet reported for a Cu-Al2O3 catalyst system. Asakura et al. [35] previously reported a high NO conversion of 90%, possibly attributable to the use of a low space velocity (36,000 l kg−1 h−1) and moderate treatment conditions. Kang et al. [36] reported an NO conversion of 60% using CuAl2O3 containing 14 wt% Cu species. This low conversion efficiency could have resulted from the use of a high space velocity, even though the heat treatment employed by Kang used a relatively low temperature of 600 °C. Yoshida et al. [34] demonstrated an NO conversion of 35% using a catalyst processed in air at 600 °C and 70% for a catalyst treated at 900 °C in H2O, with both materials containing 8 wt% Cu. However, decreased NO conversions were observed at higher temperatures, similar to results associated with an Selective Catalytic Reaction (SCR) mechanism [37–41]. However, our work did not observe any unexpected results with regard to NO conversion. This might be the case because the present catalysts having less than 8 mol% Cu comprised stable CuO-Al2O3 solid solutions. It should also be noted that NO conversion was rapidly increased to 100% in trials using the 5 and 8 mol% CuAl catalysts. This increased performance occurred after the conversions of CO and C3H6 reached approximately 80% in the vicinity of 450 °C. This behavior indicates that the oxidation states and stability of copper species in the catalyst in this work differed from those associated with other supported Cu catalysts. These factors might explain the superior performance and recyclability (Figs. S2–S5) of the present catalysts. In contrast, CO never reached complete conversion at high temperatures. Cu-based catalysts exhibit high Reverse Water Gas Shift (RWGS) reactions at high temperatures [42,43]. In this study, the concentration of CO2 increased with an increase in the conversions of CO and C3H6 (Fig. S6). However, the production rate of CO2 has slowed down in high-temperature regions. The same trend was also observed in the conversion curve of CO. The result indicated that the RWGS reaction might occur at this temperature region. This increase in the concentration of CO might also lead to a high NO reduction activity. 3.3 Transformation of the crystal phases and chemical states of the catalysts Fig. 4 shows the XRD pattern of each catalyst as acquired after evaluating the activities of these catalysts. Compared with the pattern obtained prior to these trials (Fig. 1), new peaks have appeared that are attributed to Cu metal (JCPDS 04–0836) at 43° and 50°, Cu2O (JCPDS 05–0667) at 36°, 42° and 61°, and CuO (JCPDS 48–1548) at 32° and 40° in the case of the 10 mol% CuAl catalyst (Fig. 4(e)). From these data, it is apparent that copper species dissolved excessively in the Al2O3 in this catalyst precipitated as solid Cu, Cu2O, and CuO phases under the catalytic reaction conditions involving oxidizing and reducing agents. Fig. 5 summarizes the relationship between the Cu content and the d-spacing of the Al2O3 (440) planes following activity evaluations as determined from the XRD patterns. The interplanar spacing can be seen to have increased with an increase in the copper content up to 8 mol%, while the 10 mol% CuAl showed a slight decrease. Because copper species promote the sintering of Al2O3 [44], an excess of this metal might be expected to facilitate a phase transition that reduces the concentration of copper in the solid solution. As noted above, excess copper species precipitated in the 10 mol% CuAl catalyst. These results establish that the amount of copper species that could be dissolved in the solid solution without precipitation was changed under the conditions associated with the catalytic reactions. Trials with the catalysts containing 3–8 mol% copper showed that the catalytic activity increased along with the copper loading (Fig. 3). In contrast, the activity of the 10 mol% CuAl catalyst was decreased compared with that of the 8 mol% CuAl catalyst. The CuO and Cu2O likely precipitated as a solid phase in this catalyst played different roles during the catalytic reaction compared with copper species in the solid solution. In contrast, those copper species dissolved in the Al2O3 without precipitation (even after the catalytic reaction) could possibly have increased the catalytic activity to a greater extent than the precipitated phases. XAFS data were acquired to investigate differences in the chemical states and structures of Cu phases before and after the application of CuAl catalysts to TWC reactions. Fig. 6 presents the Cu K-edge XANES spectra obtained from the CuAl catalysts. The peaks that appeared in these spectra could be primarily attributed to Cu2+ [34,45], and variations in the Cu loading did not greatly change these peaks prior to catalytic activity evaluations (Fig. 6(A)). In contrast, after the catalytic activity trials (Fig. 6(B)), the XANES spectrum of the 10 mol% CuAl catalyst exhibited a simultaneous decrease in the intensity of the peak at 9000 eV and an increase in the intensity of the peak at 9025 eV. These results are indicative of the reduction of Cu2+ species [45]. The oxidation states in these catalysts were investigated in detail by determining the proportions of Cu0, Cu+, and Cu2+ based on linear combination analysis of the height and position of the absorption edge, using the spectra of Cu foil, CuO, and Cu2O as references ( Table 2). This assessment showed that Cu2+ was initially dominant in each CuAl catalyst and that the proportion of Cu+ was increased following the catalytic reaction. Fourier transforms (FTs) of Cu K-edge EXAFS spectra were generated prior to the catalytic activity trials ( Fig. 7(A)). These data did not show peaks at 2.3 Å associated with Cu-Cu bonds [37,46], whereas peaks at 1.5 Å that were attributed to Cu-O bonds [37,47] were obtained from each catalyst. These results establish that copper in these catalysts was primarily in the Cu2+ state. Fig. 7(B) provides the FTs of spectra acquired after evaluating the TWC activities of the CuAl catalysts. The same peaks attributed to Cu-O bonds were produced. In addition, the 10 mol% CuAl catalyst provided a peak attributed to Cu-Cu bonds at 2.3 Å that was also obtained from Cu metal (Fig. 7(B)). Additional peaks were generated at 1.4 and 2.9 Å that matched the Cu-O and Cu-Cu peaks obtained from the Cu2O standard, respectively. 3.4 Reduction behavior in H2-TPR Fig. 8 shows the data from the first and second H₂-TPR cycles for the various CuAl catalysts. A large peak was produced by the catalysts containing 3–10 mol% copper. The temperature at which this peak appeared during the first cycle shifted to lower temperatures as the copper loading was increased, with values of 230, 224, 221, and 210 °C for the 3, 5, 8, and 10 mol% CuAl catalysts, respectively. Greater numbers of copper species serving as active sites would have increased the quantity of adsorption sites, hence promoting H2 adsorption and surface reactions with oxygen. The concentration gradient of oxygen species between the surface and the bulk of the catalyst would also have driven oxygen diffusion to the active sites. These behaviors evidently increased the reaction rate and so lowered the temperature. Therefore, decreases in the temperature resulted from increases in the concentration of copper species functioning as active sites. The XAFS data indicated that copper was primarily in the Cu2+ state, and it has been reported that Cu2+ can be reduced at approximately 200 °C in the presence of H₂ [39,48–53]. This suggests that the peaks that were observed can be attributed to the reduction of Cu2+ sites in the solid solution. In the 2nd cycle, the temperature of the first peak were 200,178, 178, and 163 °C, respectively. The decrease in the temperature might be due to the activation of Cu2+ in the CuAl catalyst during the first reduction and oxidation treatment, which might facilitate the diffusion of oxygen species in the catalyst. In addition, in the case of the 5, 8, and 10 mol% CuAl catalysts, a second small peak was seen at approximately 300 °C. The temperatures of the peak were 295, 285, and 265 °C for the 5, 8, and 10 mol% CuAl catalysts, respectively. In the 2nd cycle, they were 295, 290, and 280 °C, respectively. Gao et al. reported that the activation barrier for the oxidation reaction on a Cu2O surface is higher than that on a CuO surface [54]. In the present study, the existence of a Cu+ phase in the 5, 8, and 10 mol% CuAl catalysts was confirmed by the XAFS analyses. According to literature reports [39,51], a reduction peak in the vicinity of 200 °C can be attributed to the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+. Therefore, the peaks in the vicinity of 300 °C in the TPR profiles are considered to have resulted from the reduction of Cu+ sites on these catalysts. The peak during the second cycle appeared at the same temperature as that for the first cycle. This indicated that the peak was attributed to the reduction of stable copper oxide species by the strong interaction between copper and aluminum [43]. 4 Discussions 4.1 The structural feature of CuAl catalyst Shimizu et al. [39] reported that the Cu2+ sites in a CuAl2O3 catalyst having a low copper loading were predominantly in octahedral sites, based on analyses using UV–visible spectra and Cu K-edge XANES data. The ratio of copper at tetrahedral sites to that at octahedral sites is also known to increase as the Cu loading of CuAl2O4 catalysts is increased. In this study, the post-edge features of the Cu K-edge XANES data obtained from the catalysts having 5–10 mol% copper showed four peaks at 8988, 8993, 8998, and 9003 eV (Fig. 6(A)), and these peaks correspond to copper species [55]. In the case of the spectrum acquired from the 3 mol% CuAl catalyst, the resolution of these four peaks was poor, suggesting a less uniform local structure around Cu2+ sites. The copper in the defective phase might be readily reduced to Cu0 species because of the ease of expansion of the lattice of such copper species. Tikhov et al. carried out spectroscopic analyses and theoretical calculations and reported that the stability of Cu2+ and Cu+ can be changed based on their coordination states [56]. This effect was evidently associated with extended defects around the Cu2+ sites and isolated copper ions in the surface layer of the Al2O3. As noted above, the ratio of copper at tetrahedral sites to that at octahedral sites increase along with the Cu loading in the CuAl2O4 catalysts. In oxide spinels, Cu2+ ions having a tetrahedral coordination state can produce the Jahn–Teller effect in conjunction with long-range or macroscopic crystal structures [57]. Any local distortion around Cu2+ ions at these tetrahedral sites necessarily distorts the coordinating anions in next-nearest-neighbor octahedral sites. This network of interconnected localized distortions increases on a thermodynamic basis because of changes in configurational entropy. Indeed, the Cu2+ cations at tetrahedral sites would be associated with higher entropy than those in octahedral sites. These phenomena might, therefore, affect the ease with which Cu2+ is reduced to Cu+ in CuAl catalysts. Cu+ sites could be situated in Al-O-Cu+-O-Al and Cu-O-Cu+-O-Al groups in the surface layer of the γ-Al2O3 [58]. These states might lead to rapid fluctuations of the oxidation state between Cu2+ and Cu+ in the surface layer of the present CuAl catalysts, providing enhanced catalytic activity. The stability of Cu+ sites is believed to be associated with the diffusion of Cu ions into the defective spinel lattice of the γ-Al2O3. The diffusion coefficient (D) of Cu in alumina is estimated to be approximately 8 × 10−20 cm2 s−1 at 900 °C [32]. A calculation of the approximate diffusion distance, x, using the equation x = (2 D t)1/2 during time t gives a value of 0.4 nm for catalysts heat-treated at 900 °C for 3 h in air. The diffusion of Cu should, therefore, be limited to a few atomic layers roughly equivalent to one unit cell of the spinel structure of CuAl2O4. As discussed above, the Cu+/Cu2+ ratio in the 8 mol% CuAl catalyst, as determined from XANES analysis data, was in the range of 0.11 – 0.13, and so approximately corresponded to one Cu+ site per unit cell. Oxygen deficiency would be expected to cause nearby Cu atoms to be slightly positive [49], thus facilitating the adsorption of reducing species such as CO and C3H6. 4.2 The reducibility of Cu+/Cu2+ sites in H2-TPR In the H2-TPR profile, the peaks in temperature range from 200 °C to 300 °C assigned to the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu0 via Cu+ in CuAl2O4 spinel in the surface layer on the γ-Al2O3 [52,53]. The reduction of Cu+ to Cu0 was examined by calculating the ratio of the area of the second peak to that of the first peak. In the case of the first cycle, these ratios were 0.16 for 5 mol% CuAl catalyst, 0.18 for 8 mol% CuAl catalyst, and 0.30 for 10 mol% CuAl catalyst, respectively. In the case of the second cycle, they were 0.10, 0.11, and 0.13 for the 5, 8, and 10 mol% CuAl catalysts, respectively. The ratio for 10 mol% CuAl catalyst decreased in the second cycle. A direct transformation from Cu2+ to Cu0 in pure copper oxide has been shown to occur without the formation of intermediates or suboxides during H2-TPR analyses [58,60]. In addition, the apparent activation energy for the transformation of Cu2+ to Cu0 is lower than that of Cu+ to Cu0 [60]. In the reduction reaction mechanism, hydrogen can either embed into or penetrate through the lattice to expand the unit cell of copper oxide species. Thus, the ease of the expansion process is associated with the removal of oxygen from the Cu-O bond, resulting in the direct reduction of Cu2+ to Cu0 and forming stable Cu0 species. To estimate the quantity of reduced copper species, the atomic H/Cu ratios were calculated from the relationship between the area of each peak and the amount of copper species. To evaluate the reduction properties of copper oxide species in an activated state, the ratios were calculated from the peak of the second cycle. The ratios of the first peak were 1.73, 1.70, 1.71, and 1.50 for 3, 5, 8, and 10 mol% CuAl catalysts, respectively. These values indicated that the reduction properties of copper species dissolved in the surface layer of γ-Al2O3 were the same among CuAl catalysts. In the case of 3 mol% CuAl catalyst, the ratio of the first peak was 1.73, and the second peak was not observed. The result is consistent with high reducibility to Cu0 caused by the less uniform local structure around Cu2+ sites, as discussed in Section 4.1. The H/Cu ratios of the second peak were 0.20, 0.22, and 0.23 for 5, 8, and 10 mol% CuAl catalysts, respectively. Since the total of these ratios is less than 2.0 as the value of complete reduction of Cu, there might be stable copper species in these CuAl catalysts. Compared to the analysis of the XANES spectra, the ratios of the second peak to 2.0 for the 5 and 8 mol% CuAl catalysts were consistent with the proportions of Cu+ sites remaining after the TWC evaluations (Table 2). Thus, the solid solution of Cu-Al oxide system seemed to stabilize the intermediate Cu+ state at tetragonal sites by high interaction with Al in the surface atomic layers [43], as discussed in Section 4.1. These results indicate the existence of Cu+ sites with high stability even under an oxidation-reduction atmosphere like H2-TPR in present catalysts. In contrast, the ratio of the first peak and the total of these ratios for 10 mol% CuAl catalyst was lower than that of 5 and 8 mol% CuAl catalysts. In addition, the ratio of the second peak for the 10 mol% CuAl catalyst was lower than the proportion of Cu+ sites as calculated from XANES spectra. These results indicated that the precipitated Cu+ species were relatively unstable and that Cu2+ might be reduced directly to more stable Cu0 in a reducing atmosphere, lowering the catalytic activity. 4.3 The relationship between TWC performance and Cu+/Cu2+ as active sites As mentioned above, the greater performance of this catalyst can possibly be attributed to the well-dispersed Cu species in the surface layer on the Al2O3 as a solid solution. Our experiments have found the reduction activity of NO over 8 mol% CuAl catalyst was highest in TWC activity to reach its 100% reduction, although the performance of the 5 mol% CuAl catalyst was similar. However, the catalytic activity during the oxidation reaction over the 5 mol% CuAl catalyst was lower than that over the 8 mol% CuAl catalyst. This oxidation reaction might proceed via the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+, and so these results suggest that the 5 mol% CuAl catalyst had fewer stable Cu+ sites, in agreement with the Cu+/Cu2+ ratios before and after TWC evaluations (Table 2). Since an oxidation reaction and a reduction reaction co-occur in the TWC reaction, the specific copper oxidation state might affect the reactivity of these catalysts. In the case of the CO-NO and HC-NO reaction mechanisms, several workers described that the reaction is promoted by interchanges between Cu2+ and Cu+ ions [29,48,59,61]. Specifically, CO is oxidized to CO2 during the CO-NO process in conjunction with the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+. Following this, N2O is formed via the dimerization of NO followed by N2 dissociation, and Cu+ is re-oxidized to Cu2+ [29,59]. In the HC-NO reaction, C3H6 is partially oxidized and adsorbed on Cu2+ sites, while NO is adsorbed on Cu+ sites [39,40]. Therefore, an increase in the Cu+ ion concentration should promote NO reduction together with reoxidation of these ions to Cu2+, acting as adsorption sites for reducing agents. In contrast, crystalline copper species tend to induce oxidation reactions such that fewer reducing agents are available for NO reduction [30,40]. These facts suggest that Cu+ ions are easily re-oxidized to Cu2+ by active oxygen, which in turn inhibits NO adsorption. Thus, homogeneously dispersed Cu2+ and Cu+ species are essential to the complex TWC reactions that were examined in this study, and the lower activity of the 10 mol% CuAl is ascribed to the precipitation of various copper species. In particular, the XAFS results in Table 2 suggest that a precipitated Cu+ phase might not readily re-oxidize to produce Cu2+. Hence, the lower NO reduction reactivity observed in trials with the 10 mol% CuAl might have been a consequence of the copper oxidation states in this catalyst. In contrast, the XAFS analysis suggests that the copper species dissolved in the Al2O3 increased the catalytic activity of the catalyst based on transitions between Cu+ and Cu2+. Therefore, the stability of the Cu+ site might affect this behavior in the catalyst surface. Concerning the relationship between mixed state conversion of copper species and TWC, the rate of formation of Cu+ on the catalyst surface via oxidation reactions on the 8 mol% CuAl catalyst was found to be 2.2 × 10−6 s−1. It is worth noting that this value corresponds to 10% of the total amount of Cu, giving a Cu+/Cu2+ ratio of 0.31 after conversion from Cu2+ to Cu+. This value is consistent with the ratio calculated from the concentrations of the reactants (0.3% CO, 0.04% C3H6, and 0.1% NO), taking into account the Cu2+ sites for CO and C3H6 adsorption and the Cu+ sites for NO adsorption, respectively. It is believed that the oxidation reactions prepared the appropriate environment for the reduction of NO. The Cu+/Cu2+ ratio following the oxidation reactions over the 5 mol% CuAl catalyst was 0.28 and so was equivalent to that of the 8 mol% catalyst, which showed high TWC reactivity. In contrast, this value was 0.16 for the 3 mol% CuAl catalyst, suggesting that insufficient Cu+ sites were available for NO adsorption, resulting in low NO reduction reactivity. In the case of the 10 mol% CuAl catalyst, Cu2+ sites on aggregated copper particles likely promoted the oxidation reactions described above, resulting in the inactivation of the NO reduction reaction. These results indicated that the amount of stabilized Cu+ site under oxidation-reduction conditions, demonstrated by the TPR and XAFS analyses, might be a necessary prerequisite for TWC reactions. 4.4 The reaction kinetics in TWC reactions and the stability of Cu+ sites Because the TWC reaction involves a redox cycle between Cu2+ and Cu+, an assessment of kinetics could help to understand the generation and stability of various Cu oxidation states. The conversion curves acquired during the NO conversions contained a small peak in the vicinity of 330 °C for each catalyst. The apparent activation energy (Ea) values calculated from the Arrhenius equations in this region were found to be 102, 78, 66, and 88 kJ/mol for the 3, 5, 8, and 10 mol% catalysts, respectively (Table S1). The higher values at 3 and 10 mol% loadings might correspond to the Ea for dimerization on Cu+ after NO adsorption [59]. This could be the rate-limiting step in the reduction reaction of NO in this temperature range. In contrast, the value was 66 kJ/mol for the 8 mol% CuAl, which is consistent with the Ea attributed to NO adsorption on Cu+ sites [59]. Therefore, this peak can be attributed to the adsorption and subsequent dimerization of NO on Cu+ sites. These results indicate that the formation behavior of Cu+ sites from Cu2+ via oxidation reactions affects the TWC catalytic reaction. Figs. S7–S10 present plots summarizing the correlations between NO conversion efficiencies with those of the two other reactants based on the data in Fig. 3. The nominal selectivity of NO to reductants was observed. However, there was a limited relationship between the CO-NO and C3H6-NO conversion efficiencies, especially in the low conversion efficiency regions. Fig. 9 (A) and (B) show the Arrhenius plots for the CO and C3H6 conversion reactions in the TWC activities of the CuAl catalysts. The plots exhibit inflection points at 360 °C. The decrease in the slope of the Arrhenius plot for CO and C3H6 might be due to a change in the reaction mechanism of each reactant. Since a small peak in the NO conversion curves in the vicinity of 330 °C was attributed to the adsorption and dimerization of NO, the slope below 360 °C might be attributed to the oxidation reactions involving dissociative adsorption and diffusion of oxygen species. To evaluate the reaction kinetics, the Ea for CO and C3H6 reactant was calculated from the slope of Fig. 9, and these values are summarized in Table 3. The apparent activation energy values for the CO oxidation reaction (Ea _CO ) were determined in the temperature range from 200° to 280°C and below 10% conversion. These values were 71 ± 3, 68 ± 2, 53 ± 2, and 68 ± 3 kJ/mol for the 3, 5, 8, and 10 mol% CuAl catalysts, respectively. In CO oxidation reaction, the Ea _CO value of 8 mol% CuAl catalyst is smaller and different from the others. These results are consistent with the activation energy for the CO oxidation reaction at Cu sites on a supported Cu catalyst [62]. They are related to the diffusion of oxygen species as the rate-determining step [63,64]. The Ea _HC values were evaluated over the temperature range from 300° to 360°C, over which C3H6 conversion might result from reactions with oxygen species. The Ea _HC values were 69 ± 3, 60 ± 2, 62 ± 3 and 65 ± 3 kJ/mol, respectively, which correspond to the Ea for oxidation reactions accompanied by oxygen diffusion, similar to the results obtained for the CO oxidation reactions. These processes involve adsorption at Cu2+ sites in conjunction with a reduction from Cu2+ to Cu+ [65]. In the case of the oxidation reactions, the order of the Ea _HC value was 8 mol% CuAl ≈ 5 mol% CuAl < 10 mol% CuAl < 3 mol% CuAl. The Ea _CO value for the CO oxidation reaction determined for the 8 mol% CuAl catalyst was different from those for the other catalysts, and so the stability of the Cu+ sites might affect this parameter. In addition, the oxygen diffusion rate increases with increases in the concentration gradient of oxygen in the cell. The low activation energy for the oxidation reaction observed in the case of the 8 mol% CuAl is thus related to the presence of stable Cu+ sites, and the smaller frequency factor for this catalyst could be attributed to fewer Cu2+ species acting as adsorption sites for CO molecules. In contrast, oxidation reactions occurring near the Cu+ sites would be expected to generate clusters of Cu+ sites that would facilitate the dimerization of adsorbed NO. This is an important aspect of the NO reduction reaction and would likely promote this process. Since it appears that the energy barriers to the adsorption and dimerization of NO were equivalent for the 8 mol% CuAl catalyst, the immediate dimerization of NO might be associated with a change in the oxidation state of Cu species in the vicinity of stable Cu+ sites. Because a similar Ea_ NOads value was obtained for the 5 mol% CuAl, both catalysts likely contained stable Cu+ sites. The presence of such sites evidently promoted NO adsorption and subsequent reduction, resulting in complete NO conversion at high temperatures. The lack of a decrease in NO conversion can also be ascribed to the ability of these stable Cu+ sites to promote the adsorption of NO. The XAFS analyses indicated that the Cu+ sites were highly stable even under oxidation or reduction conditions in the case of the 8 mol% CuAl (Table 2). These results suggest that the activity was improved primarily by the stability of the Cu+ sites rather than by increases in the number of active sites upon adding more copper. The presence of stable Cu+ sites appear to promote the reduction of nearby Cu2+ sites and so enhances NO reduction following adsorption and dimerization, resulting in high TWC performance. In conclusion, the stability of the chemical state of mixed copper species and Cu+ sites is an influential factor for TWC activities. The state is generated after the initial oxidation reaction of CO and C3H6 by Cu2+-Cu+ change. The TWC study of novel Cu-added Al2O3 was conducted by XAFS, TPR, TEM and reaction analyses and concluded that 8 mol% Cu containing CuAl catalyst could show the highest performance of TWC as the stabilized solid solution state with stabilized Cu+ species. 5 Conclusion Cu-added γ-Al2O3 (CuAl) catalysts were prepared and investigated with regard to TWC activity while assessing the oxidation states of Cu species. The results of XRD analyses and TEM observations indicated that the copper dissolved in a surface layer of the γ-Al2O3 support to form a solid solution. The TWC conversion profiles for CO, C3H6, and NO using these CuAl catalysts showed that the catalytic activity increased along with the copper loading on going from 3 to 8 mol%. NO conversion is rapidly promoted and reached 100% at 600 °C in 5 and 8 mol% CuAl catalysts. The conversion occurred after the conversions of CO and C3H6 reached about 80% at around 450 °C. In contrast, the catalytic activity of the 10 mol% CuAl catalyst was less than that of the 8 mol% CuAl catalyst, because CuO and Cu2O were precipitated as a solid phase. XRD data obtained before and after TWC evaluations showed that the copper oxidation states differed between catalysts. In the case of the 10 mol% CuAl catalyst, CuO and Cu2O were precipitated as a solid phase, decreasing the catalytic activity. Assessments using XRD and XAFS analysis before and after TWC evaluation demonstrated variations in Cu+/Cu2+ ratios in these catalysts. The Cu+ sites in the 5 and 8 mol% CuAl catalysts were also found to be highly stable within the solid solution, which explained the results of the TPR analyses. An analysis of reaction kinetics indicated that the 8 mol% CuAl catalyst showed lowest activation energy in CO oxidation reaction below 360 °C. This oxidation reactions with oxygen species produces Cu+ state, resulting in high NO conversion reactivity. The study of novel Cu-added Al2O3 was conducted by XAFS, TPR, TEM and TWC reaction analyses, and concluded that 8 mol% Cu containing CuAl catalyst could show the highest performance of TWC as the stabilized solid solution state with stabilized Cu+ species. coredata.dc:description: Cu-added γ-Al2O3 (CuAl) catalysts having varying Cu loadings (3, 5, 8, and 10 mol%) were prepared at 900 °C. The effects of the copper oxidation states and the stability of these states under oxidizing and reducing atmospheres were examined. The use of these materials as three-way catalysts (TWCs) was also assessed. Analyses by X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy indicated that copper oxide species were well dispersed and formed a solid solution in a surface layer of the γ-Al2O3. The TWC activity was found to increase with the addition of copper, and the 8 mol% CuAl catalyst showed very high performance despite being heat-treated at high temperatures. In the case of the 10 mol% CuAl catalyst, the excess Cu loading resulted in the precipitations of copper species on the γ-Al2O3 surface, which decreased catalytic activity. The oxidation states also differed between these catalysts. X-ray absorption fine structure and temperature-programmed reduction data demonstrated variations in copper oxidation states among the catalysts before and after oxidation and reduction treatments. The 8 mol% CuAl catalyst had a high Cu+/Cu2+ ratio and contained stable Cu+ species during both oxidation and reduction trials. The stability of the copper oxidation states is evidently a factor affecting catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: The chemical state and Cu+ stability for three-way catalytic performance of Cu-added Al2O3 catalysts
